name: Mission Hill Luxury Apartment
Cozy Colonial (entire home) near Lower Mills
transit: Getting here on public transportation couldn't be much easier than it is. There are two options from South Station in Boston, which is the main train and bus terminal and the destination of the free Silver Line bus shuttle from Logan Airport. You can either take the Red Line to Ashmont Station, and then transfer to the Mattapan Trolley and ride it to Mattapan Square, or you can take the MBTA Commuter Rail train to Morton St. (Fairmount Line). It's about a 12-15 minute walk from either one of these stations to the house. The cost of these two trains is about the same - approximately $2.50 per person one way - and while the Commuter Rail trains are more expeditious, the Red Line trains run more frequently than do the Commuter Rail trains. There are also city bus stops very close by. Visit the Boston MBTA website for all bus and train schedule and fee information.
access: The entire home is available for your use. I have a few personal belongings in the closets, though, there is plenty of additional room for your hanging garments and luggage. The dresser in the 2nd bedroom is empty and available for your use; unfortunately, however, the dresser in the master bedroom is full of my personal items and isn't available for your use. I have lots of books and movies for adults and children alike, and toys for children as well. The kitchen is fully stocked with dishes, pots, pans, utensils, and cooking spices which you are welcome to use. The washer and dryer is located in the basement and is also available to you.

transit: There are two primary modes of public transportation available to you within walking distance from 565 Massachusetts Avenue, the train (Orange Line or Green Line) and the bus (SL4/SL5/43/1). * Orange Line Train @ Mass Ave Station ** Walk left out my apartment door and walk a few blocks down the left side of the street. You’ll see the station on your left. Oak Grove goes to Downtown and Forest Hills goes outbound to Jamaica Plain and Roxbury.  * Green Line Train @ Symphony Station ** Walk left out my apartment door and walk a few blocks down the right or left side of the street. You’ll see the station on both sides of the street. Lechmere will go towards the Pru, Copley, Boylston, Downtown Crossing area. Heath Street will go down towards the MFA, Longwood, and Brigham Circle.  * SL4/SL5 Bus (aka Silver Line) **To get there, turn right out of my apartment until you get to Washington Street. If you want to go to Downtown/South Station then cross the street and you'll see a bus stop in fro

name: Hilltop2- 2beds 4.6m to DT/CT near T w/freeprk
transit: There is 24 street parking in front of the house, NO meter to feed. From Logan airport the easiest way is to take a taxi, Uber or lyft and it will take you 15-20 minutes with no traffic . You could also take free silver line bus to south station, then switch to the Red line. Hop on the red line to Ashmont, stop at Fields corner station. Then walk 8 minutes to the address .  If you are commuting via transportation there are buses #15 and 17 in front of the building. There are 2 buses literally right across from the house and from there you can go to the historical places in Boston Bus #15 rides about 20 minutes to Ruggles T station to catch orange line subway. transit: LMA is served by two rail stations at opposite ends of Longwood Avenue: "Longwood" (on the MBTA Green Line's "D" branch) and "Longwood Medical Area" (on the "E" branch). Several public bus routes serve the area and commuter rail service is available at nearby Ruggles Station. MASCO offers shuttle buses (generally for affiliated personnel only) around the Longwood Medical Area and between Harvard's Cambridge Campus and the Medical Campus (M2). The M2 shuttle is free for passengers holding a Harvard ID, and tickets can be purchased at multiple locations. 70 Parker Hill Avenue is located 2 blocks up from the Mission Park Station on the "E" Line of the GreenLine of Boston's famous transit system, commonly referred to as the "T."  For those with physical challenges, Taxi/Uber/Lyft is recommended getting to and from this Parker Hill location.

transit: Lyft & Uber are abundant throughout the city, but Boston is a proud walking city best-seen on-foot! There are lots of things you can see at every corner with a free 20-minute walk. So, let's earn that cannoli! The Freedom Trail and Bunker Hill Monument are steps away, and the USS Constitution and Charlestown Navy Yard are an 8-minute walk. TD Garden, North End, and Cambridge are a 14-minute walk, and Haymarket, Government Center, Quincy Market & Faneuil Hall are a 20-minute walk! Also, the Charlestown Navy Yard Ferry to Long Wharf is a 14-minute walk. From Long Wharf you can access ALL of the city's tours (from historic to whale watching) as well as the Seaport District, New England Aquarium, Boston Tea Party, Custom House, Rose Kennedy Greenway, Greenway Carousel, Faneuil Hall, and Boston Harbor!
access: Guests have access to the front lobby, emergency exits, laundry room, and our home and anything in it (as well as fire detectors and extinguishers). Enjoy! Free amenities include (1) assigned parking space, high-speed 5G wifi, and Amazon Fire Stick with Amazon Prime, Netflix, Hulu Live, and Hulu. *SLEEPY PANDA A/C POLICY* During warmer months a free window A/C unit is available by request. Kindly, we ask our guests to: *Please use A/C responsibly *Turn-off A/C when leaving the home *Try opening a window or using a fan before the A/C Our planet thanks you! Eco-Chic at heart, we very much hope you understand Sleepy Panda's need to balance your accommodations with our environment. We are reasonable hosts and will make every attempt to avoid a penalty, but please note a $30 surcharge will be applied to guests who heedlessly use A/C. After all, it is our mutual responsibility to reduce our global impact! Thank you again!

transit: I personally use BLUE BIKES to get everywhere (i.e. Boston's bike rental service), as cycling is consistently faster [and more fun/scenic] than public transit and about as fast as a car.  ^ It's $2.50/ride or $10 for a day pass.  ^ location: Warren St at MLK Blvd {across the street and to the left} The public transit in Boston is ~$2/ride and, in my opinion, frustratingly slow (#spoiledinasia). Even though the triple bus pickup to the Ruggles metro and Dudley bus stations is incredibly convenient, I recommend tourists on a time clock utilize the ride-sharing apps UBER and LYFT in combination with public transportation.  ^ An Uber Pool or Lyft Line to Downtown Crossing only costs $3-$8 at off-peak times.
access: Bedroom, Bathroom, Kitchen, Balcony (for smoking), Basement (for laundry)

Inviting 1 Bedroom South End
transit: In addition to getting around by walking, Boston city taxis, and Uber, you will be able to use the subway (the “T”) to access other parts of Boston. Below is a brief summary of the subway lines nearby. Green Line. Take a left out the front door, walk down Cumberland and take a right on Huntington. At the next intersection cross West Newton and you will see the entrance to the Green Line station. This will take you into downtown Boston or the outbound will take you to the Symphony and the Museum of Fine Arts. Orange Line. Take a left out the front door. Take another left onto St. Botolph. Walk until you hit Massachusetts Avenue. Take a left and you will see the Massachusetts Avenue station of the Orange Line. This line will take you to Downtown and connects to the Blue Line and the airport as well as the North End and Charlestown.

name: Bed in Beacon Hill!
Cozy Studio in the South End
transit: In addition to getting around by walking, Boston city taxis, and Uber, you will be able to use the subway (the “T”) to access other parts of Boston. Below is a brief summary of the subway lines nearby. Green Line. Take a left out the front door, walk down Cumberland and take a right on Huntington. At the next intersection cross West Newton and you will see the entrance to the Green Line station. This will take you into downtown Boston or the outbound will take you to the Symphony and the Museum of Fine Arts. Orange Line. Take a left out the front door. Take another left onto St. Botolph. Walk until you hit Massachusetts Avenue. Take a left and you will see the Massachusetts Avenue station of the Orange Line. This line will take you to Downtown and connects to the Blue Line and the airport as well as the North End and Charlestown.

name: Cozy Room on Cul de Sac
transit: The Forest Hills T Station is 5 minutes walk from the apartment. Forest Hills is a major hub and you can easily reach almost any part of the Boston area quite easily from there. The Orange Line connects with all other lines and gives you access to the entire city and most of the Boston Metropolitan area. The Orange also integrates with commuter lines and bus lines. There are also multiple "Blue Bike" bike sharing stations in Jamaica Plain and bike paths that bring you easily into all areas of the city and surrounding towns. Needless to say, you'll be well connected to everything.
access: Use the kitchen freely just clean up after yourself...wash your dishes, clean your spills. The kitchen has an easy-use Nespresso coffee machine, the coffee is good, plentiful and free. Use the living room, television, back yard patio, fire pit and barbecue. You might need to buy charcoal and lighter but the area is available and comfortable. Basic civility and decent manners are much appreciated. You can also use the washer and dryer and there is an iron and ironing board. So, if you need to spruce up your wardrobe for a night out, I got you covered.

transit: If you are arriving from the airport, the easiest way would be to order a taxi/uber. It should cost between $20 and $30 depending on time and traffic and will take between 15 and 25 minutes. Unfortunately there is no efficient public transportation that would take under 1 hour.  If you are arriving to South Station via Train or Bus you can either take the Purple Line (Metro) which should be about 30 minutes or and Uber/Taxi which will cost $15 to $20 and take about 15 minutes. If you are driving, the address is very easy to find via GPS Navigation, and I have a parking spot behind the house.  Getting around after you have arrived is very easy. The apartment is especially well connected for car transportation and there is no place in Boston or Cambridge that should take you more than 15 minutes. As for public transportation, it will vary depending on your destination, but the fastest access is to Harvard Square and the Cambridge area. Here are some times to main points of interest: - Ha

Extra toothbrushes and bars of soap are yours if you forget them :) You'll have your own space in the shower to keep your toiletries and space on the bathroom counter to keep other things.  Most importantly: I want you to feel like this is your home.  If you're looking for glasses?  Open up all the cabinets!  Check out everything for what you need because I'm sure I already have it. Full washer and dryer in unit and your own laundry bag. A power strip next to your bed for all of your charging needs. Amazon Prime Videos, Hulu, Netflix, and Showtime (with basic cable). name: Room private, WC shared, near BU Harvard
transit: Bus stops are about 3-4 min walk for buses 66, 64, 57, and a Commuter rail stop "Boston landing" is steps away. Ticket for the commuter rail train is included in a weekly or monthly pass for Boston metro link. Otherwise, it is about $2.50, and it can be bought onto your phone and stored on your phone. The train takes you to Fenway, Back Bay Station (Orange line, Green line at Copley (Central library, Newbury Street, Prudential Center, Apple store,  Historic South End's Arts and fine restaurants quarter); and last stop is South Station where you can connect with Silver line to get to the Airport, or walk around Financial district (Fine Dining, Tea Party museum, walk to Waterfront)

name: Shared Space in a Quiet Neighborhood 1.1
transit: I personally use BLUE BIKES to get everywhere (i.e. Boston's bike rental service), as cycling is consistently faster [and more fun/scenic] than public transit and about as fast as a car.  ^ It's $2.50/ride or $10 for a day pass.  ^ location: Magnolia St at Dudley St {5 minutes away} The public transit in Boston is ~$2/ride and, in my opinion, frustratingly slow (#spoiledinasia). Even though the triple bus pickup to the Ruggles metro and Dudley bus stations is incredibly convenient, I recommend tourists on a time clock utilize the ride-sharing apps UBER and LYFT in combination with public transportation.  ^ An Uber Pool or Lyft Line to Downtown Crossing only costs $3-$8 at off-peak times.
access: The front porch, kitchen, and living/dining room are all common places that are great for talking. The three bathrooms are also shared, though, so please be respectful with your shower time.

Even though the triple bus pickup to the Ruggles metro and Dudley bus stations is incredibly convenient, I recommend tourists on a time clock utilize the ride-sharing apps UBER and LYFT in combination with public transportation.  ^ An Uber Pool or Lyft Line to Downtown Crossing only costs $3-$8 at off-peak times.
access: The front porch, kitchen, and living/dining room are all common places that are great for talking. The three bathrooms are also shared, though, so please be respectful with your shower time.

transit: Choose your own adventure. We own a car for my husband’s commute to work, but otherwise we walk, take the T, or I often bike. For visitors looking to explore downtown Boston, it’s probably best to leave your car at the house and take the Orange T line into downtown. Around JP, we’d recommend walking or driving if you’re not feeling up to it or the weather is bad. To other out-of Boston neighborhoods, like Brookline, driving or biking is best.

name: Sunny Beacon hill apartment, ideally located
★Beacon Hill Penthouse★Brand New★Luxury Renovation
transit: Most tourists do almost everything on foot.  This location has a walker score of 98 - "A walkers paradise".  There are two train lines that are a 5 minute walk - the Green T line and Red T line.  They will get you everywhere else you might like to go.  There are also taxis everywhere.  Just step out and hail one on Charles Street.  For those driving, there are two parking garages close by - one on Charles Street (2 minute walk) and  one on the Common (3 minute walk). Conveniently located near: 3 minutes to Boston Common Park 3 minute walk to Starbucks 1 minute away from restaurants and takeout places 5 minute walk to Green/Orange/Red lines 10 minute walk to Whole Foods 10 minute to start of Freedom Trail 10 minutes to downtown Boston 5 minutes to the Old State House (with a yummy steak house inside) 10 minute walk to Quincy Market 15 minute walk to the aquarium 15 minute walk to the North End and Little Italy (or 5 minutes by subway) 10 minute walk to Charles River 15 minute subway rid
access: Everything, the apartment is yours! The entire apartment, and everything that Boston has to offer within walking distance.

name: Eco-Chic World Traveler~Free Parking~Freedom Trail
transit: Lyft & Uber are abundant throughout the city, but being a proud walking city, on-foot is the best way to explore Boston! There are lots of things you can see at every corner with a free 20-minute walk. C'mon, let's earn that cannoli! Scoring 91 on (Website hidden by Airbnb) Freedom Trail & Bunker Hill Monument are steps away, USS Constitution is an 8-minute walk, TD Garden, North End, and Cambridge are a 14-minute walk, Haymarket & Government Center are a 20-minute walk, and Quincy Market & Faneuil Hall are a 25-minute walk! We know we said 20, but it's worth the extra 5-minutes, we promise! Also, the Charlestown Navy Yard Ferry to Long Wharf is a 14-minute walk, and from Long Wharf you can access all of the city's tours (from historic to whale watching) as well as everything the other side of the city has to offer! Walk to Seaport District or visit attractions like the New England Aquarium, Boston Tea Party, Custom House, Rose Kennedy Greenway & the Greenway Carousel, Faneuil Hall, an
access: Guests have access to the front lobby, emergency exits, laundry room, and our home and anything in it (as well as fire detectors and extinguishers). Enjoy! Free amenities include (1) assigned parking space, high-speed 5G wifi, and Amazon Fire Stick with Amazon Prime, Netflix, Hulu Live, and Hulu. *SLEEPY PANDA A/C POLICY* During warmer months a free window A/C unit is available by request. Kindly, we ask our guests to: *Please use A/C responsibly *Turn-off A/C when leaving the home *Try opening a window or using a fan before the A/C Our planet thanks you! Eco-Chic at heart, we very much hope you understand Sleepy Panda's need to balance your accommodations with our environment. We are reasonable hosts and will make every attempt to avoid a penalty, but please note a $30 surcharge will be applied to guests who heedlessly use A/C. After all, it is our mutual responsibility to reduce our global impact! Thank you again!

name: Cozy and Bright
transit: I personally use BLUE BIKES to get everywhere (i.e. Boston's bike rental service), as cycling is consistently faster [and more fun/scenic] than public transit and about as fast as a car.  ^ It's $2.50/ride or $10 for a day pass.  ^ location: Warren St at MLK Blvd {across the street and to the left} The public transit in Boston is ~$2/ride and, in my opinion, frustratingly slow (#spoiledinasia). Even though the triple bus pickup to the Ruggles metro and Dudley bus stations is incredibly convenient, I recommend tourists on a time clock utilize the ride-sharing apps UBER and LYFT in combination with public transportation.  ^ An Uber Pool or Lyft Line to Downtown Crossing only costs $3-$8 at off-peak times.

transit: The MBTA Orange Line stops at the Chinatown station and the Tufts Medical Center station, located within and at the southern edge of the district, respectively. Boylston station on the MBTA Green Line is located just beyond the northwest corner of Chinatown. Just east of Chinatown, South Station is served by the MBTA's Red Line, Silver Line, and Commuter Rail. South Station also accommodates Amtrak, the long-distance rail to New York City and other cities on the Northeast Corridor and also service to the west, including Chicago. The bus terminal at South Station handles regional buses to New England, New York City, Washington DC, Albany (New York), and other destinations. The New England destinations include Concord (New Hampshire) and Portland (Maine). The regional and national bus companies include Greyhound Lines, Peter Pan Bus Lines, Megabus, and Bolt Bus. In Chinatown itself, Chinese-owned bus service Lucky Star/Travelpack provided hourly connections with New York's Chinatown. Ent

name: Quiet and spacious room near T
Eco-Chìc Panda Zen~Free Parking~City Square
transit: Lyft & Uber are abundant throughout the city, but Boston is a proud walking city best-seen on-foot! There are lots of things you can see at every corner with a free 20-minute walk. So, let's earn that cannoli! The Freedom Trail and Bunker Hill Monument are steps away, and the USS Constitution and Charlestown Navy Yard are an 8-minute walk. TD Garden, North End, and Cambridge are a 14-minute walk, and Haymarket, Government Center, Quincy Market & Faneuil Hall are a 20-minute walk! Also, the Charlestown Navy Yard Ferry to Long Wharf is a 14-minute walk. From Long Wharf you can access ALL of the city's tours (from historic to whale watching) as well as the Seaport District, New England Aquarium, Boston Tea Party, Custom House, Rose Kennedy Greenway, Greenway Carousel, Faneuil Hall, and Boston Harbor!
access: Guests have access to the front lobby, emergency exits, laundry room, and our home and anything in it (as well as fire detectors and extinguishers). Enjoy! Free amenities include (1) assigned parking space, high-speed 5G wifi, and Amazon Fire Stick with Amazon Prime, Netflix, Hulu Live, and Hulu. *SLEEPY PANDA A/C POLICY* During warmer months a free window A/C unit is available by request. Kindly, we ask our guests to: *Please use A/C responsibly *Turn-off A/C when leaving the home *Try opening a window or using a fan before the A/C Our planet thanks you! Eco-Chic at heart, we very much hope you understand Sleepy Panda's need to balance your accommodations with our environment. We are reasonable hosts and will make every attempt to avoid a penalty, but please note a $30 surcharge will be applied to guests who heedlessly use A/C. After all, it is our mutual responsibility to reduce our global impact! Thank you again!

name: Private Deck Overlooking Boston + King Bed!
Garden Level One Bedroom Apartment w/ Private Deck
Cheap place Back Bay
Cozy Spot Near Northeastern 3.51
transit: I personally use BLUE BIKES to get everywhere (i.e. Boston's bike rental service), as cycling is consistently faster [and more fun/scenic] than public transit and about as fast as a car.  ^ It's $2.50/ride or $10 for a day pass.  ^ location: Warren St at MLK Blvd {across the street and to the left} The public transit in Boston is ~$2/ride and, in my opinion, frustratingly slow (#spoiledinasia). Even though the triple bus pickup to the Ruggles metro and Dudley bus stations is incredibly convenient, I recommend tourists on a time clock utilize the ride-sharing apps UBER and LYFT in combination with public transportation.  ^ An Uber Pool or Lyft Line to Downtown Crossing only costs $3-$8 at off-peak times.
